para.sentence: The mutual inductance M of two coaxial circles of radius a and b with centers at a distance h apart is given in cgs units by \frac{{c^{2}}M}{2\pi}=ab\int_{0}^{2\pi}(h^{2}+a^{2}+b^{2}-2ab\cos\theta)^{-1/2 }\cos\theta\mathrm{d}\theta=2ab\int_{-1}^{1}\frac{t\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1+t)(1- t)(a_{3}-2abt)}}=2abI(\mathbf{e}_{5}), where c is the speed of light, and in (19.29.11),

The method of §19.29(ii) uses (19.29.18), (19.29.16), and (19.29.15) to produce 2abI(\mathbf{e}_{5})=a_{3}I(\boldsymbol{{0}})-I(\mathbf{e}_{3})=a_{3}I( \boldsymbol{{0}})-r_{+}^{2}r_{-}^{2}I(-\mathbf{e}_{3})=2ab(I(\boldsymbol{{0}}) -r_{-}^{2}I(\mathbf{e}_{1}-\mathbf{e}_{3})), where a_{1}+b_{1}t=1+t and r_{\pm}^{2}=a_{3}\pm 2ab=h^{2}+(a\pm b)^{2} is the square of the maximum (upper signs) or minimum (lower signs) distance between the circles.

Application of (19.29.4) and (19.29.7) with \alpha=1 , a_{\beta}+b_{\beta}t=1-t , \delta=3 , and a_{\gamma}+b_{\gamma}t=1 yields \frac{3{c^{2}}}{8\pi ab}M=3\!R_{F}\left(0,r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2}\right)-2r_{-}^{2 }R_{D}\left(0,r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2}\right), or, by (19.21.3),
A simpler form of the result is M=(2/{c^{2}})(\pi a^{2})(\pi b^{2})R_{-\frac{3}{2}}\left(\tfrac{3}{2},\tfrac{3 }{2};r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2}\right).
References for other inductance problems solvable in terms of elliptic integrals are given in Grover (1946, pp. 8 and 283).
